newsitem.title: ITALY: CYCLING-TONKOV SURVIVES RISKY DAY WITH GIRO LEAD INTACT.
newsitem.headline: CYCLING-TONKOV SURVIVES RISKY DAY WITH GIRO LEAD INTACT.

text.p: Russian Pavel Tonkov's lead in the Giro d'Italia cycling race survived a squall of attacks in Thursday's mountainous stage where risks came at every hairpin bend.
The Russian's key team-worker Giuseppe di Grande from Sicily won the 214-km leg from La Spezia, and later admitted that he too had taken a chance in going for victory.
"It was a risk to leave Pavel in the last three kilometres, especially if he had had trouble, but it worked out," said di Grande.
"It would have been dangerous if there had been more than three kilometres to go," said Tonkov.
"There had been a lot of attacks but they were doing it to show that they are still strong."
The Sicilian held off Spain's Marcos Serrano and third-placed Alexandre Shefer from Kazakhstan as five riders contested the sprint at this Ligurian resort.
Tonkov arrived 12 seconds later with his chief rivals France's Luc Leblanc and Italian Ivan Gotti, so the top three overall remained unchanged.
Tonkov, who took over the leader's jersey on the third day in San Marino, still leads Leblanc by 41 seconds with Gotti one minute seven seconds in arrears.

Tonkov was unshaken by constant attacks from Leblanc, Gotti and others as the head of the race toiled over the 1061-metre Passo del Faiallo and the 1287-metre Monte Beigua, spread-eagling 150 riders as far as 25 minutes behind.
The severe twists of the narrow final descent over most of the remaining 20 kilometres caught out several riders, often at 60 kph.
Colombian Jose Gonzalez was among the leaders until he crashed into a grass bank.
He came in with Tonkov's group, but Shefer and Leonardo Piepoli fought back from a spill with a TV motorcycle to contest the finishing sprint.
Piepoli, who finished fifth, also rose to fifth place overall. He was the only faller who needed medical treatment, having stitches for a cut chin.

The leaders' final close encounter came when Axel Merckx, son of five times Giro winner Eddy, led the group out of a corner. The Belgian and his co-leaders had to switch violently to avoid a photographer's motorcycle which had stopped.
